verses.text: Jesus entered Jericho and was passing through town.
verses.comment: Jericho was a city of historical significance, once conquered by Israel (Joshua 2:1). Jesus’ journey through Jericho foreshadows salvation arriving where once there was judgment.

verses.text: There was a man named Zacchaeus, who was a chief tax collector, and he was rich.
verses.comment: Tax collectors were notorious for their collaboration with Rome and dishonest gain (Matt. 9:9). Zacchaeus’ position amplifies the mercy of Jesus in what follows.

verses.text: He wanted to see who Jesus was, but because he was short, he could not see over the crowd.
verses.comment: Zacchaeus’ humble stature is reminiscent of the childlike humility Jesus calls for (Matt. 18:2-4), showing God’s preference for the lowly.

verses.text: So he ran ahead and climbed a sycamore tree to see Jesus, because Jesus was about to pass by.
verses.comment: His eagerness depicts seeking after Christ with determination, echoing Luke 13:24’s encouragement to strive to enter through the narrow door.

verses.text: When Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said, 'Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for today I must stay at your house.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ personal invitation signals divine initiative in salvation, and foreshadows his call to sinners (Matt. 9:13): God seeks us first.

verses.text: So Zacchaeus quickly climbed down and welcomed Jesus joyfully.
verses.comment: Joy accompanies repentance and welcoming Christ, as in the joy among angels when a sinner repents (Luke 15:10).

verses.text: All the people saw this and began to grumble, saying, 'He has gone in to be the guest of a sinful man.'
verses.comment: Just as in Luke 15:2, Jesus associates with sinners, showing his special mission to save the lost and the scandal of mercy.

verses.text: But Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, 'Look, Lord, I will give half my possessions to the poor, and if I have cheated anyone of anything, I will pay back four times as much.'
verses.comment: Zacchaeus’ restitution exceeds legal requirements (Lev. 5:16; Ex. 22:1), showing genuine repentance that produces fruit—an implicit affirmation of works accompanying faith.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Today salvation has come to this house, because he too is a son of Abraham.'
verses.comment: Jesus declares household salvation, linking it to Abraham’s blessing (Gen. 12:3), and emphasizing the unity of faith and family—suggestive of household faith traditions.

verses.text: For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.
verses.comment: Echoes Ezekiel 34:16 about God as true shepherd—pointing to Jesus’ identity as the Divine Shepherd actively pursuing the lost.

verses.text: While they were listening to this, he proceeded to tell a parable, because he was near Jerusalem and people supposed that the kingdom of God was about to appear at once.
verses.comment: Jesus addresses the common expectation of a rapid, earthly kingdom (Acts 1:6-7), clarifying that God’s plan unfolds in stages.

verses.text: He said, 'A nobleman went to a distant country to receive royal power and then return.'
verses.comment: While the nobleman reflects Christ's Ascension and promised return (Acts 1:9-11), the imagery highlights the kingly authority of Jesus.

verses.text: He called ten of his servants and gave them ten minas. He said, 'Do business with these until I come back.'
verses.comment: This parable is parallel to the talents in Matt. 25:14-30, emphasizing stewardship and faithfulness over time before Christ’s return.

verses.text: But his citizens hated him and sent a delegation after him, saying, 'We do not want this man to rule over us.'
verses.comment: Refers to the human rejection of divine kingship, echoing the rebellion of the nations against the Lord’s Anointed (Ps. 2:1-3).

verses.text: When he returned after receiving the kingdom, he summoned the servants to whom he had given the money, to find out what they had gained by trading.
verses.comment: Describes final judgment and accountability; the king rewards service (Matt. 16:27), reaffirming Christ as the judge and king.

verses.text: The first came and said, 'Master, your mina has made ten more minas.'
verses.comment: Reflects faithful stewardship that brings reward—this motif of multiplication frequently exemplifies spiritual growth.

verses.text: He replied, 'Well done, good servant! Because you have been faithful in a small matter, you will have authority over ten cities.'
verses.comment: Reward for faithfulness foreshadows the saints reigning with Christ, a glimpse of the future kingdom and the progression from faith to greater responsibility.

verses.text: The second servant came and said, 'Master, your mina has made five more minas.'
verses.comment: The lesser reward implies the principle of proportionate reward for diligence, highlighting individual responsibility.

verses.text: He said to him, 'And you shall be over five cities.'
verses.comment: Christ’s distributive justice affirms the principle of merit and stewardship within the kingdom.

verses.text: Then another servant came and said, 'Master, here is your mina; I have kept it laid away in a cloth.'
verses.comment: Parallels the fearful servant in Matthew’s talents (Matt. 25:24-25); the failure to act with God’s gifts implies wasted spiritual potential.

verses.text: 'I was afraid of you, because you are a hard man. You take what you did not deposit, and reap what you did not sow.'
verses.comment: Rather than honest fear, this reveals a lack of trust in God’s goodness—contrary to the proper reverence of the Lord.

verses.text: 'He said to him, 'By your own words I will judge you, wicked servant! You knew I am a hard man, taking what I did not deposit and reaping what I did not sow?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ words underline judgment by one’s own actions and confessions (Matt. 12:37), emphasizing accountability and the reality of divine justice.

verses.text: 'Why then didn’t you put my money in the bank, so that when I returned I could have collected it with interest?'
verses.comment: Even a modest effort with gifts is rewarded; spiritual gifts are meant for the good of the community and not for idle keeping.

verses.text: Then he said to those standing by, 'Take the mina from him and give it to the one who has ten minas.'
verses.comment: Spiritual fruitfulness is rewarded, and neglect is penalized; God’s justice restores gifts to those who best use them.

verses.text: They said to him, 'Master, he already has ten minas.'
verses.comment: The concern of the onlookers reflects a worldly notion of fairness, yet divine generosity often transcends human calculations.

verses.text: ‘I tell you, to everyone who has, more will be given. But from the one who does not have, even what he has will be taken away.’
verses.comment: Describes the principle of growth in spiritual life: those who receive grace and co-operate with it are entrusted with more (Matt. 13:12).

verses.text: 'But as for these enemies of mine who did not want me to rule over them, bring them here and kill them in my presence.'
verses.comment: A stark depiction of judgment aligns with Psalm 2:9: Christ’s kingdom brings both mercy and ultimate justice to those who reject him.

verses.text: After he had said this, Jesus went ahead, going up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Here begins the climax of Jesus’ journey; Jerusalem is not just a destination, but the place for the fulfillment of prophecy and sacrificial atonement.

verses.text: As he approached Bethphage and Bethany, at the place called the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples ahead.
verses.comment: The Mount of Olives holds messianic significance (Zech. 14:4). Jesus’ entry signals fulfillment of OT prophecy.

verses.text: He told them, 'Go into the village ahead of you. As you enter it, you will find a colt tied there, one that has never been ridden. Untie it and bring it here.'
verses.comment: The colt is connected to Zechariah 9:9, where the Messiah comes humble and riding on a donkey.

verses.text: 'If anyone asks you, ‘Why are you untying it?’ say, ‘The Lord needs it.’'
verses.comment: Jesus’ identification as ‘Lord’ in this context conveys authority and hints at his divinity.

verses.text: Those who were sent went and found it just as he had told them.
verses.comment: Jesus’ foreknowledge emphasizes his prophetic and divine nature.

verses.text: As they were untying the colt, its owners asked, 'Why are you untying the colt?'
verses.comment: The disciples encounter resistance, but in obedience, fulfill Jesus’ instructions—spiritual obedience is key.

verses.text: They replied, 'The Lord needs it.'
verses.comment: Again, the use of ‘Lord’ for Jesus continues the theme of his authority and divinity.

verses.text: They brought it to Jesus, threw their cloaks on the colt, and set Jesus on it.
verses.comment: The act of spreading cloaks signals recognition of royal identity. See 2 Kings 9:13, where cloaks are spread for a king.

verses.text: As he rode along, people spread their cloaks on the road.
verses.comment: Public homage to Jesus as king; such gestures affirm messianic kingship.

verses.text: As he approached the descent from the Mount of Olives, the whole crowd of disciples began praising God joyfully with loud voices for all the miracles they had seen.
verses.comment: The joyful praise recalls Psalms of ascent (Ps. 118:26) and connects public worship to journeying with Christ.

verses.text: They shouted, 'Blessed is the King who comes in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven and glory in the highest!'
verses.comment: Directly invokes Ps. 118:26; ‘glory in the highest’ recalls the angels’ praise at Jesus’ birth (Luke 2:14)—underlining his kingship and divinity.

verses.text: Some of the Pharisees in the crowd said to Jesus, 'Teacher, rebuke your disciples!'
verses.comment: Religious leaders protest recognition of Jesus as messiah; often, institutional resistance confronts authentic worship.

verses.text: He replied, 'I tell you, if they kept silent, the stones themselves would cry out.'
verses.comment: Creation itself worships its Creator; even inanimate nature proclaims Christ’s divinity (Hab. 2:11).

verses.text: As he got closer and saw the city, he wept over it.
verses.comment: Jesus’ tears reveal his deep compassion and prophetic grief over Jerusalem’s rejection (Matt. 23:37).

verses.text: 'If only you had understood on this day what would bring you peace! But now it is hidden from your eyes.'
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s spiritual blindness fulfills Isaiah’s prophecy (Isa. 6:9-10); peace is found in recognizing the Messiah.

verses.text: 'For the days will come upon you when your enemies will build a barricade around you, surround you, and hem you in on every side.'
verses.comment: Prediction of the siege of Jerusalem, fulfilled in AD 70—Jesus’ prophetic authority is again made clear.

verses.text: 'They will dash you and your children to the ground, and not leave one stone upon another, because you did not recognize the time of your visitation.'
verses.comment: Echoes Daniel 9:26 and Luke 21:6, underscoring judgment for rejecting the Messiah—‘visitation’ suggests a divinely appointed time.

verses.text: Then Jesus entered the temple and began to drive out those who were selling.
verses.comment: Jesus’ cleansing recalls Jeremiah’s warning (Jer. 7:11) and prefigures the restoration of sacred worship.

verses.text: He said to them, 'It is written, My house will be a house of prayer; but you have made it a den of thieves.'
verses.comment: Combines Isaiah 56:7 and Jeremiah 7:11, emphasizing the sanctity of worship and warnings against corruption—true worship must be pure.

verses.text: He taught in the temple daily. The chief priests, scribes, and prominent leaders among the people sought to destroy him.
verses.comment: Daily teaching demonstrates Jesus’ authority, continuity with temple worship, and the growing plot against him.

verses.text: But they could not find a way to do it, for all the people hung on his every word.
verses.comment: Christ’s authority is rooted not just in miracles, but in his teaching; public devotion protects him—an image of the Word attracting true worshipers.
